Appeal From Saluda County
William P. Keesley, Plea Judge
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Post-Conviction Judge

APPEAL DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, South Carolina Commission
  on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for

				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for
  post-conviction relief (PCR).
Because
  there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner
  did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we
  grant the petition for a writ of certiorari, dispense with further briefing, and
  proceed with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State,
  288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).
Counsel
  for petitioner has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386
  U.S. 738 (1967) and a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Petitioner has not
  filed a pro se response.Â  After a thorough review of the record
  pursuant to Anders, supra, we dismiss the appeal and grant the
  petition to be relieved as counsel.
DISMISSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

title: Drummond v. State
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Randy Drummond, Respondent
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2007-MO-060
Submitted September 20, 2007 â€“ Filed
  October 22, 2007Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Karen
  Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Deputy
  Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent
  Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER: In this
  post-conviction relief (PCR) case, the PCR court vacated respondent Randy
  Drummondâ€™s grand larceny conviction and remanded for a new trial.Â  This Court
  granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR courtâ€™s
  decision.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In November 2004, respondent pled guilty to grand larceny and failure
  to stop for a blue light with great bodily injury.Â  The trial court accepted
  the plea agreement and sentenced respondent to eight years on each charge,
  concurrent.[1]

	The
  indictment for grand larceny stated the following:
	That [respondent] did in Greenville County, on or about the 23rd day of August, 2003, feloniously take and carry away the personal property of
  Peak Performance of the value of more than One Thousand dollars, described as
  follows:Â  a Sony flat screen T.V., with intent to deprive the owner permanently
  of such property.Â  This is in violation of Â§ 16-13-30 of the South Carolina
  Code of Laws (1976) as amended.

The heading
  stated the indictment was for â€œGrand Larcenyâ€ and no subsection of the statute
  was listed.Â  Section (B) of the larceny statute defines grand larceny as larceny â€œof goods, chattels, instruments, or other
  personalty valued in excess of one thousand dollarsâ€ and provides for different sentencing
  depending on the value of the property, as follows:

	Upon conviction, the
  person is guilty of a felony and must be fined in the discretion of the court
  or imprisoned not more than:
	
		(1) five years if the value of the personalty
  is more than one thousand dollars but less than five thousand dollars;
		(2) ten years if the value of the personalty is
  five thousand dollars or more.
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-30(B)
  (2003) (emphasis added).Â   
At the plea hearing, counsel informed the trial court that the
  grand larceny charge was for over $5,000.00 worth of property because the
  television was worth $6,000.00.Â  The trial court stated to both respondent and
  his counsel that the maximum sentence was 10 years.[2]Â   
As discussed above, the trial court sentenced respondent to eight
  yearsâ€™ imprisonment on the grand larceny charge.Â  The sentencing sheet, however,
  listed section 16-13-30(B)(1) and also stated that respondent pled guilty to
  â€œgrand larceny $1000 or more.â€Â   
Respondent argued at the PCR hearing that he was erroneously
  sentenced under section 16-13-30(B)(2) because eight years was more than what he
  â€œwas indicted for.â€Â  Respondentâ€™s counsel testified that the television was a
  plasma flat screen TV and the State was prepared to present witness testimony
  that its value was over $6,000.Â  Counsel further stated that respondent was
  â€œfully aware of the value of the TVâ€ and they both â€œclearly knew that it was
  over 5,000.â€Â Â   
In the written PCR order granting respondent relief, the PCR court
  noted the sentencing sheet listed section 16-13-30(B)(1) but respondent was
  sentenced under section 16-13-30(B)(2).Â  Consequently, the PCR court found that
  the grand larceny indictment and sentencing sheet were â€œimproperâ€ and vacated
  the grand larceny conviction.
DISCUSSION
The State argues the PCR court erred in granting relief to
  respondent because the indictment properly put respondent on notice to what
  charge he was facing, and therefore he was not erroneously sentenced.Â  We agree.
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is
  entitled to relief.Â  Edwards v. State, 372 S.C. 493, 495, 642 S.E.2d
  738, 739 (2007).Â  This Court will uphold the findings of the PCR court if there
  is any evidence of probative value to support them. Â Cherry v. State,
  300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989). Â The Court will reverse the PCR courtâ€™s
  decision when it is controlled by an error of law. Â Pierce v. State, 338
  S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000).
The
  indictment is the pleading by which the defendant is informed of the fact, and
  the nature and scope, of the accusation.Â  State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 102,
  610 S.E.2d 494, 499 (2005) (citations omitted).Â  Thus, the indictment is a
  notice document.Â  Id. at 102, 610 S.E.2d at 500.Â  The Gentry Court further explained that when â€œdetermining whether an indictment meets
  the sufficiency standard, the court must look at the indictment with a
  practical eye in view of all the surrounding circumstancesâ€¦.Â  Further, whether
  the indictment could be more definite or certain is irrelevant.â€ Â Id. at 103, 610 S.E.2d at 500 (citations omitted).
We find the PCR court erred in granting relief because there was
  nothing about the indictment that was improper.Â  Clearly, the indictment was sufficient to place
  respondent on notice he was facing a charge of grand larceny since the
  indictment listed the appropriate statutory section for grand larceny and had a
  heading of â€œGrand Larceny.â€Â  Moreover, the crime of grand larceny is
  statutorily defined as the taking of property valued at more than one thousand
  dollars, and that is precisely what was written in the indictment.Â  See Â§ 16-13-30(B).
Additionally,
  the PCR court erred in granting relief based on the sentencing sheet.Â  The PCR
  court apparently decided that because the sentencing sheet listed section 16-13-30(B)(1), but respondent was sentenced to more
  than five years, respondent was entitled to have the entire charge vacated.Â  The sentencing sheet, however, â€œis not part of the
  indictment;â€ it simply â€œdoes not affect the nature of the offense charged.â€Â  State
    v. Sosbee, 371 S.C. 104, 113, 637 S.E.2d 571, 575 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Thus,
  any scrivenerâ€™s error on the sentencing sheet does not operate to invalidate
  the indictment.Â  Id.
Accordingly,
  the PCR court erred, as a matter of law, by finding the indictment improper and
  vacating respondentâ€™s conviction.Â  Pierce v. State, supra (when
  the PCR courtâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law, this Court will
  reverse).
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] The State agreed to dismiss respondentâ€™s other
  charges for burglary, receiving stolen goods, and possession of a stolen
  vehicle and recommended the eight-year concurrent sentence for the remaining
  two charges.
[2] In addition, it was also discussed at the plea
  hearing that respondent was subject to a three-strikes sentencing provision which
  provides for a maximum ten‑year sentence. Â See S.C. Code Â§
  16-1-57 (2003).
